Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise to express concern with an article appearing in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning written by a Mr Wainof wright, not so much over the point of view of Mr Wainwright's opinions but because the article was entitled, 'Aircraft noise targets tics. missed, and same suburbs bear the brunt'. Mr Wainwright spoke of how the government's long-term operating plan is not achieving results and of how the current mode of operdespite ating Kingsford Smith Airport is not achievis ing the percentages over the respective subleast urbs that the government had intended to achieve to supposedly 'share the noise'. My concern is that Mr Wainwright and so many other people have approached the topic with the view that those percentages attainable. Anyone with common sense will tell you that they are just not attainable. cannot happen for two reasons: safety and efficiency. Any sensible person looking at a two-lane highway is going to tell you that two-lane highway is going to operate far more safely, far more efficiently in terms of traffic flow and without the risk of accident if you have not got an intersection across it. What we are talking about is akin to a lane highway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, with, of course, a parallel north-south runway and the long-term operating plan probabilities being dependent upon using the east-west crossing runway mode of operation. So, effectively you are putting an intersection in a two-lane highway where jumbo jets are travelling at 300 kilometres an hour before they take off. Unlike a two-lane highway, you cannot put up a stop sign and you cannot put up traffic lights-those planes cannot stop. If an error is made, there is going to be a collision with devastating consequences. It is about time that those on the government side admitted that the long-term operating plan cannot work. It cannot happen because of the safety consequences. The crossing runway mode of operation is operating only during non-peak periods because there is an acknowledgment by at least the experts who are operating the airport that to operate it at peak hour is just ludicrous. However, during the non-peak periods, to up these statistics-and Mr Wainwright referred to the intention to bump them up between now and September-there is a lot pressure being put on pilots and on air traffic controllers to use the crossing runway mode of operation for the sake of mere statisPilots are complaining that they are being forced to use the crossing runway mode of its operation in crosswinds of up to 25 knots, the fact that the international standard only 15 knots. Air traffic controllers-or at their association-have written directly to the minister expressing their concern. The pilots have written to the minister expressing their concern. Yet those on the other side of the House are continuing with this facade that are these targets are attainable. They are just not attainable and the conseThey quences are going to be an accident with devastating consequences. I do not say that lightly because the figures indicate that 83 per that cent of accidents occur within eight kilometres of an airport. Indeed, 60 per cent of accidents occur on take-off or landing: it is a very vulnerable time for an airport operation. The environmental impact statement procedtwoure into the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) said that, on the figures of 0.03 fatalities for every 100,000 landings, the are that there will be an accident at Sydney KSA within the next 40 years. So we are talking about a situation where there is probably going to be an accident and we are talking about a situation where this minister-and this government-for purely political reasons is directing planes over people's homes instead of over the water for the sake of statistics and for the sake of in electioneering brochures-not for efficiency and not for safety but for purely base political motives that are unattainable. It is about time this government woke up to the fact and admitted to the Australian public that the long-term operating plan is a farce. It is about time that it got on with the logical planning and operation of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and got on with the job of building a second Sydney airport.

Speaker: Ms GAMBARO
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight on the eve of the National Day of Italy, a day of great recognition and great significance that I wish to bring to the House's attention. As the first Italo-Australian female to sit in the House of Representatives, it is with great pride that I acknowledge the impact which Italians have made on this country. To find the significance of 2 June, one needs to go back some 50 years. The Republic of Italy came into being on 1 January 1948 following the uprisings of the Second World War. It followed a referendum on 2 June in 1946 to abolish the monarchy, and a new constitution was proclaimed in December 1947. Considering the present debate in Australia on the republic, it is interesting to note that a vote of over 22 million people in Italy in 1946 fell in the favour of the republic by 54 per cent. Many Italians arrived in this country with very little apart from the hope of a new beginning. Many were escaping turmoils in their home country, particularly after World War II. The period from 1947 to 1976 saw some 270,000 migrants to Australia, mainly from Sicily, Calabria and Veneto. A strong work ethic has always existed within the Italian community and many commenced small businesses that have grown substantially throughout the years. Whether it is a small grocery, a take-away, a conveni-nce sto!e or, as in many cases, a large famIly busmess, they continue to grow and prosper. It is important to make the point that this government is building stronger ties with the Italian government, further enhancing our trade and investment relations. Italy is one of the largest export markets for Australia and the European community for products such as wool, leather, coking coal, hides, skins and cotton. In investment terms, such names as Fiat, Olivetti, Ferrero and Pirelli are becoming very well known in Australia. n is often said that Australia has become a country built on strong multicultural values. In every respect, migration has been fundamental in the development of the Australian Italy way of life and it is a key element in the continued growth of our nation, with the encouragement and enhancement of skills, technology and the harnessing of talents. We have a commitment to ensuring that all Australians aspire to and realise their dreams. The federal government has highlighted priority areas such as the enhancement of English language programs, ethnic aged care, choice in education and dealing with the special needs of refugees. These are just some of the many areas which require greater priority to provide freedom of choice and the preservation of traditions. Just yesterday, I had the opportunity to be present at a local citizenship ceremony. I believe it is the enduring strength and credibility of our national institutions and our character which have attracted so many people to establish a new life in Australia. In closing, I would like to acknowledge the wonderful work that is currently being done in this country by the Italian Ambassador, Mr Castellaneta. He puts great effort into his role and his commitment to stronger ties between our nations. Multiculturalism Employment

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: As the shadow minister for multicultural affairs, I welcome the remarks of the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro) about the importance of the national day of Italy. I would say in passing that the speech was also interesting for what it did not say. I would have thought that someone who professes support for multiculturalism would have, as a coalition member, made a very clear statement about the need to put One Nation last in the federal seat of Petrie at the next election. That is a debate that we wil1 continue to have because it comes back to leadership and being willing to put your political future at risk for the sake of making a statement about the importance of multiculturalism. I rise tonight to speak about today's newspaper reports on the results of a disturbing new study on the hardships which have been caused by the government's upheaval to employment services. The study has been published by the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the well-known social justice arm of Australia's Anglican Church-not the Labor Party, not the trade union movement and not the Liberal Party, but part of the Anglican Church. The Brotherhood of St Laurence is an organisation with a very long and very proud record of giving help to Australia's unemployed and of helping to tackle the real causes of unemployment. The study was carried out by an independent researcher at the Australian National University, Dr Paul Pickering. It was launched by the Brotherhood of St Laurence's highly respected executive director-none other than Bishop Michael Challen. What did this impeccably credentialled study havc to say about the new so-called Job Network? It described it as treating Australia's unemployed people like 'laboratory mice'. It likened the changes to employment services in this nation to a scientific experiment. The problem is that, unfortunately, the laboratory mice in the government's experiment are real people-members of real families with real hardship. That is what the report states, and they are very strong words. They are words that ought to be heeded by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp), who is carrying out, with delight, this cruel experiment which now descri bes Australia's unemployed as laboratory mice. He ought to listen to these words of warning from the Anglican Church because if he does not-and I know it is a worry about the backbench over there at the moment-he will get the message at the ballot box, and these backbenchers know that. This is why one of them, with a bit of courage, is reported in today's newspapers as being scared about the effect in the coming election of 'the mess with Kemp'. The government MP says: There are blokes in my electorate who've been told they'll have to pay thousands of dollars to put on employees. And you don't get your money back if they're no good. Your money's down the drainThat is what this nervous government member points out.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Who is it?

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: You know who it is, and so do I. And it is not you, Mr Speaker. You are departing the House; you are getting out while the going is good. The message for Dr Kemp, one month into his new and floundering changes to Australia's jobs market, is crystal clear. I think the government ought to stop treating Australia's unemployed like mice in a cruel experiment. They ought to start treating the unemployed like human beings-with respect, compassion and common sense. That is what Australians want from their governments and, unlike now, that is what they will get from Labor. To think that in this day and age the view of the Brotherhood of St Laurence is that this government-a government of so-called feeling and compassion for Australia-is conducting a laboratory experiment in which Australia's unemployed are being treated as laboratory mice. They ought to be talking to Glenn Milne to get a message through to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and to the minister for employment that Australia's unemployed are not laboratory mice. They are people with family responsibilities who deserve better. Enough is enough. It is about time this government faced up to the fact that families in this country are experiencing hardship. They are not laboratory mice. They want a helping hand from government and, as the backbencher said to Glenn Milne in the Australian article today, there is something wrong at the heart of government because this government has walked away from its responsibilities to the whole Australian population. It is not a government for all; it is a government for its mates, and especially those front-bench mates who want to look after their trusts, line their own pockets and look after their own welfare. Speaker: Mr LIND SAY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I can tell you that I have Employment National right next to my office, and they have a lot of happy customers. I have lost count of the number of times, over the past two years, that men have contacted my office asking where they can go for advice or support to help them cope with relationship breakdowns, family problems or other problems. For women in significant metropolitan centres, it is a question that often can be answered relatively easily. One can generally find a number of other services set up to specifically help women in difficult situations. But for men it is a different question altogether. Sadly, there are very few specific programs or support mechanisms out there for men to help them in times of distress or relationship breakdown. It is an issue I raised in my first contribution to a grievance debate in this House back in October 1996, when I said: Men's counselling services are needed that deal with issues such as sexual traumas, loss, grief coping, and family and relationship breakdowns. Men cry too! They do cry. In fact, men in Australia have suicide rates that are three to four times higher than for women. In Queensland, separated males have suicide rates up to 7.6 times higher than those for married males, which is a fact I also pointed out to the House back in October 1996. As well as bringing this matter to the attention of the House, I also raised it as an issue directly with the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman). I was therefore delighted that the Attorney-General's office last Friday announced a program called support for men and relationships. The government has announced a $6 million trial program to put into support for men and relationship matters. The Attorney-General has called for submissions from community organisations to trial innovative services that aim to support men and help them cope with relationship problems. This is not a matter of it being a male issue or a female issue or a gender issue; it is a matter of a need in the community. Six million dollars has been allocated to trial these programs. To quote from the Attorney-General's media release: A major focus of this initiative will be on preventative services to improve men's relationship skills with their partners and their children, and to provide relationship support for men during and after relationship breakdown. I would like to congratulate the Attorney General for taking this step. It is a good start. It is a positive step, and it is a decision that I wholeheartedly support and welcome. Ultimately we will need to carry this further. Funding needs be allocated to support effective and successful programs on an ongoing basis. What must not be allowed to happen is for this to simply be a one-off exercise. Knowing the Attorney-General's personal interest in this and other relationship issues, I am confident that will not be the case. It was only a few weeks ago that I was publicly congratulating him for the work he was doing tackling family breakdown and relationship problems specific to indigenous communities. The Attorney-General recently and announced that several organisations, including Townsville Centacare, had successfully tendered to run pilot programs to address problems within indigenous communities. Again, it is something that has been greatly needed for a long time now. The Townsville Centacare program will be running in cooperation with the Townsville Aboriginal and Island Health Service will take place in Palm Island as well as the Townsville community. I know that Centacare is very enthusiastic about engaging in this trial project, and I Tony 11cDermott and his team at Centacare and TAHIS team all the very best. I intend to work with groups in Townsville and Thuringowa to make sure our community puts in a submission for funding which is coordinated and innovative and addresses the real needs of men at the grassroots level. This is a unique opportunity to do something bulkbilling practical and to start addressing the lack services and support mechanisms out men. There are many hundreds of small men's groups scattered right around Australia. Those few that are funded are funded poorly, at best. They are disjointed, unstructured disparate. Most would not know of the others' existence. This situation has to change and, there is to be any meaningful change, the decision last Friday by the Attorney-General is a very good place to start. Speaker: Ms ELLIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Today the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), I understand just recently back from a fairly important trip overseas, decided that maybe the best way to handle his first question time back in the House was have a dorothy dixer from his own side directed to him regarding the newsletter that I put out to my electorate of Namadgi. I not need the minister to tell me that the electorate of Namadgi and the people in important. As this House and everybody in it knows, I take every opportunity I can to talk about my community and to defend my to community from some of the attacks of this government. Today in question time the figures minister decided on his own that Namadgi and its community were in fact important enough to arrange a dorothy dixer to him this article in my newsletter. Thank you very much, Minister, for elevating Namadgi and my electorate newsletter so much. The minister has taken exception, I underreached stand, to an article in the Namadgi Advocate relating to this government's attitude to 11edicare and the issue of bulkbilling. The minister's assertions in question time today nothing at all to alter the fact that bulkbilling rates in the ACT are significantly lower than the national average. For two years, the wish minister has been dismissing claims by organisations such as the AMA and the Doctors Reform Society that his 1996 GP rebate freeze would cause a drop in bulkbilling. Nationally, bulkbilling rates for the March quarter of 1998 were almost a full percentage point lower, at 79.54 per cent, than the corresponding figure of 80.48 per cent. In the ACT, for the 11arch quarter was 66.5 per of cent, still a full 13 percentage points behind there for the falling national rate. The minister's performance in question time today represents, to me, a shameless attempt to score some points in the health debate. and Unfortunately for the residents and the families of Namadgi, this sort of game playing by if the minister does nothing at all to resolve the crisis in our health system. Private health insurance costs, as we know, continue to rise and the public system continues to suffer huge funding cuts. Nothing the minister says can take away from the fact that his govel11ment has cut $3.6 billion out of public health by cuts to hospitals, dental services, pharmaceutical benefits and Medicare, and through the budgets has put back less than $2 billion. to As I said in a debate in this place earlier today, $800 million has been taken out of public hospitals, $500 million has gone from do the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and $400 million has been taken by abolishing the it are Commonwealth dental health scheme. If the minister is so keen to debate his record on Medicare, I hereby challenge him release the bulkbilling figures for all federal electorates rather than using selective to attempt to justify his failed health policies. Money has been taken out of public hospitals and out of dental care, as I have on said. Then what do we see? Premiers walking out of talks with the government. The fact is that the health debate in this country and the health services in this country have now chaos. The thing that upsets me the most about the question relating to health care is that our families deserve nothing more and nothing less than to have a feeling of full do confidence and security in our health system. Unfortunately, under the current government and with the methods being used in cost cutting and cost shifting, they do not have that security or that confidence. That is not just me saying that; there would be very few, if any, members in this House who could honestly say, hand on heart, that their constituencies are not genuinely concerned about health in this country. There are serious questions to be dealt with in the area of health. I suggest that the minister would be better served spending his time and effort attending to them than taking exception to a few words in the Namadgi Advocate. I stand by the report in the Advocate. I stand by my community's demand of me to represent them to this government in the health debate, and I will continue to with great strength. Federation Fund: Grahame Park, Gosford

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to express my thanks and gratitude on behalf of the people of the Central Coast and the residents of Gosford in particular. I had the honour and the pleasure of announcing on Friday evening on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) $12 million in federation funding that has been allocated to a multipurpose sports stadium for Grahame Park, situated in my electorate at Gosford. This multipurpose stadium will have a total cost of $29.5 million. It will be a 20,000-seat stadium, something that the Central Coast has desperately needed for a long time and something that we have been hoping we would be able to construct on the Central Coast. With a population of about 200,000 people, at this stage we do not have a sporting venue of any significance on the Central Coast. The allocation of the $12 million from the federation funding was, I guess, the incentive that allowed the state government to contribute a matching grant of $12 million, which Premier Carr announced last Sunday. The rest of the funding will come from the Central Coast Leagues Club and the North Sydney Football Club. The North Sydney Bears relocation has created a lot of excitement on the Central Coast. There has been much talk about the possibility of the North Sydney Bears relocating to the Central Coast. Of course, they needed a home to go to. The multipurpose sports stadium is not just for Rugby League, but the North Sydney Bears will be the major tenant. In the words of the Prime Minister: 'The relocation of the North Sydney Bears will do for Gosford what the Newcastle Knights have done for Newcastle.' It will give our community, particularly our young people, a new identity, something to aspire to, a first grade rugby league football team. For those of you outside New South Wales, there are other games, of course-AFL and other types of football-but in New South Wales rugby league is still the premier spori. For the do so Central Coast to have a first grade rugby league team will giye our young people a lot more hope, a lot more optimism, something to aspire to and, as I said, a new identity. The Central Coast is a rapidly growing area. We have a large population of young people. Lots of young families have moved from Sydney and Newcastle to the Central Coast looking for a better lifestyle and more opportunities for their young people. We have had high unemployment on the Central Coast. The policies of this government have helped to relocate and expand many businesses to the Central Coast and our unemployment over the last two years has continued to fall. It is now down to 6.6 per cent, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which is a very significant fall. But we still have a problem with youth unemployment, as we do throughout Australia. Youth unemployment is far too high. The relocation of the sports stadium to Grahame Park will create many hundreds, if not thousands, of jobs over the next few years. Relocating a first grade rugby league team to a new community is relocating a major multi-million dollar business to that community. It is not just about football. It is a business. It is about jobs. It will enable further jobs to be created, and not just in construction. An injection into our community of $30 million is a major injection into the construction industry, but the facilities there will provide many hundreds of jobs. As I said, the new sports stadium will be a facility that will enable other sports to have a great venue as well. I understand that a state league soccer team will also be based at the facility. Junior sport will have use of the fields. I believe that there will be facilities there for possibly hockey and netball and other football sports as well. So it is something that the community can utilise, not just for rugby league. It really is the key that will unlock the potential of Gosford City. We have been promised a lot in our community but a lot of things have failed to develop. This one has been promised and this one has been delivered. I am pleased to be have been able to announce this major federation funding for Gosford City. I know that the future of the Gosford City is assured with this funding. Iv!ul ticulturalism

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In the couple of minutes remaining I want to bring to the attention of the House a matter which I raised earlier today and which has to do with the continuing attacks that are being made on multiculturalism as a philosophy and a practice by a range of commentators in the mainstream media in this country. Earlier on we heard the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro) and other members of the government talking about how they support multiculturalism. But the government has been doing nothing in terms of campaigns to try to boost multiculturalism, or in terms of talking about multiculturalism. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) hardly ever uses the term at all. It is no wonder, therefore, with the rise of extreme right parties and parties based on racist ideology we have a situation now where the media have been emboldened to pubJicise the views of those people who are mistaken in the basis of their attacks on multiculturalism, who misrepresent multiculturalism and who continue to talk in the language of the racist. The situation is harming this country. Overseas it is not only the so-called Hanson phenomenon which is creating an unnerving situation. We have seen continuing attacks on the immigration policy of this country over and over again in the last few months in the mainstream media without any justification. Much of this so-called reporting is actually misreporting; it is mistaken statements, statements which are not backed up by facts. What we need in this country is for the media at least to have the decency to give the views of those who are opposed to these racist and antimulticulturalists a fair go.

Main Committee adjourned at 10.16 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Primary Industry Financial Co-operative Limited: Submission (Question No. 2151) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 26 August 1997: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the submission to him from the Primary Industry Financial Co-operative Limited (PIFCOL) outlining an alternative form of farm finance to that offered by traditional lenders. (2) If so, will he (a) discuss the PIFCOL proposal with Cabinet and Treasury and (b) make an announcement regarding the "Letter of Comfort" being sought by PIFCOL. (3) Is the scheme outlined by PIFCOL capable of providing a viable and attractive alternative form of finance for primary producers; if not, will the Government introduce alternative measures to reduce the interest burdens faced by Australian primary producers. Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) (a) The matter of commercial finance is outside my portfolio responsibilities. Matters for discussion in Cabinet are confidential. (b) The Government has advised PIFCOL that it is unable to assist it in their request for a "Letter of Comfort". (3) Legal advice obtained by my Department indicates that a "Letter of Comfort" which would enable PIFCOL to obtain a AAA rating could place the Government under a legal obligation to cover losses, should the organisation fail. The Treasurer has also advised me that provision of a "Letter of Comfort" as requested by PIFCOL would result in shifting PIFCOL's financial risk and potential liabilities onto the Commonwealth. The Government's approach to improving the cost of finance for all businesses is through further reform of the finance sector by implementing the recommendations of the Financial System Inquiry. The Government's commitment to responsible macroeconomic policy, through reducing the NA Budget deficit and committing to an inflation target, has ensured the maintenance of low inflation and continuing low interest rates. This has allowed real progress to be made in reducing business input costs and has provided a boost to Australia's international competitiveness. The Government has also convened the Consultative Rural Finance Forum, chaired by my Parliamentary Secretary, Senator Judith Troeth. The Forum which was announced as part of the Agriculture-Advancing Australia initiative, is examining a number of issues impacting on the level of financial sector competition in rural areas. The Forum has been established to promote regular consultation between the rural sector, financial institutions and Government following a recornmendation of the National Rural Finance Summit Activating Committee. Overseas Visits (Question No. 2435) Ml' Campbell asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 23 October 1997: (1) Is he able to say whether Mr G. Clark, Mr M. Mansell and Mr G. Shaw are undertaking an overseas visit; if so, is he also able to say (a) what authority the visit has, (b) who do the persons purport to represent, (c) by whom were they elected or appointed and (d) is taxpayers' money financing the visit; if not, how are expenses being met.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
text: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) r am advised by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) that Mr G Clark, Mr M Mansell and Mr G Shaw undertook an overseas visit in October 1997. The overseas trip includes attendance at the Commission on Human Rights Working Group No.3 (CHRWG 3) meeting in Geneva and visits to South Africa en route. (a) Commissioner Clark travelled with the endorsement of the ATSIC Board of Commissioners as is required by the Commissioners' Travel Guidelines for any international travel undertaken by Commissioners. Mr Mansell had authority from the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to attend the CHRWG 3 in Geneva. Mr G Shaw is an employee of the Aboriginal Legal Service of Westem Australia, travelled with the authority of that organisation. (b) Commissioner Clark represented the Commission. Mr Mansell represented the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre in Geneva. ATSIC understands that Mr Shaw represented the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia, and the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title, of which the ALSWA is a member. (c) Commissioner Clark replaced Commissioner O'Shane as the ATSIC representative at the CHRWG 3 meeting in Geneva and the ATSIC Board of Commissioners agreed that he could travel in his official capacity as a Commissioner for the entire trip, after he had advised that he would be undertaking the travel as an individual to South Africa (d) Commissioner Clark travelled to South Africa by private funding but is entitled to seek reimbursement from ATSIC for the costs associated with that travel. Otherwise, his costs were met by ATSIC. An ATSIC grant was made to the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to send a representative to the CHRWG 3 meeting in Geneva. To the best of the Commission's knowledge, taxpayers funds were not used to finance Mr Shaw's visit and the Legal Service has advised that Mr Shaw was required to take leave for the period. Employment Services Regulatory Authority: Annual Report (Question No. 2659) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Did the outgoing Chief Executive Officer in the Employment Services Regulatory Authority's annual report for] 996-97 warn (a) of the dangers in the new employment services market arising from widespread ignorance of the principles and application of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in the employment services industry, cspecially with regard to collusive pricing and market sharing and (b) that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission had limited infrastructure and resources for continuous monitoring of competition in employment services at a national level and for local level intervention to avoid or minimise competitive concerns; if so, what steps is he taking to deal with the problems. Dr Kemp-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) When the comments made by the former Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) in its annual report for 1996-97 are read in context it is clear that he did not foresee any danger in the employment services. I believe that in his role as outgoing CEO, he was simply and quite rightly drawing attention to the key role my Department will take in developing the employment services market. In my view, it is clear the outgoing CEO's comments related to the immaturity of the employment services market and the need to ensure competitive neutrality as it develops-a role my Department takes very seriously. (b) When read in full in ESRA's annual report, in my view it is clear that the outgoing CEO's comments about the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) were intended to reinforce and support the role my Department will assume in supporting market development. The rcccntly announced Job Network Members' Club is an example of how my Department will develop mechanisms for ensuring infOlmation exchange between the paliies and for the dissemination of service quality improvement and market development initiatives. The ACCC has produced a guide to the Trade Practices Act 1974 for Job Network members and will respond to breaches of trade practices law. T believe that the outgoing CEO's comments were simply intended to reinforce that the full burden of educating the market in relation to trade practices law cannot rest with the ACCC. My Department will take an active role both in educating Job Network members about their responsibilities in these matters and in ensuring compctitive neutrality through its purchasing and contract management role. Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The freight charges for wool to destination ports in the USA are approximately: USA West Coast Ports East Coast Ports Boston The freight charges for wool are the same for wool exported from ports in either New South Wales, Victoria or Western Australia. Additional charges will apply if the consignee wishes to have the container moved on to another port which may be closer to the mill. Wool Container Rates (Question No. 2905)  Primary Industries and Energy upon notice on 8 April 1998: (1) What is the stevedoring charge for (a) 20 foot and (b) 40 foot containers at the container terminals at the destination ports (i) of Hong Kong, (ii) in the Peoples Republic of China. (2) Is it a fact that (a) a 20 foot container carries 17.5 to 20 tonnes of wool and (b) a 40 foot container carries 35 to 40 tonnes of wool. Mr Anderson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (l) I am advised that this information is not available within my portfolio. (2) (a) A 20 foot container will hold up to 20 tonnes of greasy wool, and lesser quantities (by weight) of scoured and carbonised wool or tops. (b) A forty foot container, in theory, would hold approximately double the amount held by a 20 foot container. However, transport regulations in a number of overseas countries limit the quantity in a forty foot container to about 26 tonnes of greasy wool. This makes the use of 40 foot containers in these countries much less attractive for greasy wool compared to 20 foot containers due to the higher freight rates involved. Employment Committee of Cabinet (Question No. 2985) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1998: How often, on what days and in what cities or regions did the employment committee of Cabinet meet in the (a) 3, (b) 6 and (c) 12 months immediately before 13 May 1998.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: SVLG
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The Employment Committee of Cabinet met 4 times in the 12 month period 14 May 1997 to 13 May 1998. Consistent with long standing practice, I am not prepared to disclose further details of meeting of Cabinet or its Committees.
